fields.headline: More on Bowyer and Woodgate
fields.bodyText: Bowyer rebels as Leeds try to limit the damage December 19: Leeds place Lee Bowyer on the transfer list after he refused to accept a fine of four weeks wages imposed by the club. For sale: multi-million pound misfit Richard Williams: Putting Lee Bowyer on the transfer list only four days after the end of the proceedings in Hull crown court might be a gigantic bluff. Fans stick by Bowyer December 19: Where it all began, outside the Majestyk nightclub in City Square, Leeds United fans gave their verdict on the star's effective sacking: referee, it's not fair. The way you see it Your views: What you think of the Bowyer - Woodgate controversy. Leader comment Leeds should be seen to act. O'Leary 'taking blood money' December 18: David O'Leary has been accused of profiteering from the attack on student Sarfraz Najeib. Pressure on Leeds United to punish players December 17: There have been calls for Leeds United to be tougher against drunken loutishness by its young millionaires following the release of David O'Leary's book on the trial. O'Leary revelations turn stomach Richard Williams: David O'Leary's description of his 'ordeal' makes an interesting and tasteless counterpoint to the words of the father of the attacked student Sarfraz Najeib. Letting the side down Gary Younge on how a night at the Majestyk cast the shadow of racism over the city and its football club. The rise and fall of Woodgate Back to basics: Observer Sport visits Jonathan Woodgate's old haunts and discovers he came across as 'a bit of a get'. Audio: 'It was a loyalty thing ... a macho thing' Martin Wainwright at Hull crown court on how an insult thrown on a drunken night in Leeds ended with a vicious attack. (4mins 50) Woodgate and Bowyer had violent histories December 14: Jonathan Woodgate and Lee Bowyer both had histories of violence - but they were kept from the Hull crown court jury. Woodgate avoids prison after guilty verdict December 14: Jonathan Woodgate was ordered to undertake 100 hours community service after being found guilty of affray over a brutal street attack on a student. He was cleared of the more serious charge of grievous bodily harm with intent. Lee Bowyer walked free from Hull crown court after being cleared of causing grievous bodily harm with intent and affray.
